canonical_explanation.text: Capacity tells us how much a container can hold. We compare containers to find which holds more and which holds less. A full container has no more room. A half-full container is filled to the middle. An empty container has nothing in it. We can measure capacity using non-standard units like cups, glasses, or mugs.
rules: Capacity is the amount a container can hold.
We compare using: holds more, holds less, holds the same.
Full means the container has no more room.
Empty means the container has nothing in it.
Half-full means the container is filled to the middle.
Non-standard units like cups, glasses, and mugs can measure capacity.

questions.question_text: Which holds more water: a bucket or a cup?
questions.explanation_correct: A bucket holds much more water than a cup. Buckets are much larger containers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A bucket is a large container and holds many cups of water.

questions.question_text: Which holds less: a spoon or a jug?
questions.explanation_correct: A spoon holds much less than a jug. Spoons are very small containers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A jug can hold many spoonfuls of liquid. The spoon holds much less.

questions.question_text: Which holds more: a glass or a swimming pool?
questions.explanation_correct: A swimming pool holds much more water than a glass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A swimming pool is enormous compared to a tiny glass.

questions.question_text: A glass is filled to the top with milk. The glass is:
questions.explanation_correct: When a glass is filled to the top, it is full.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filled to the top means the glass is full — it cannot hold any more.

questions.question_text: A bottle has no water in it at all. The bottle is:
questions.explanation_correct: When a container has nothing in it, it is empty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No water at all means the bottle is completely empty.

questions.question_text: A jug has water up to the middle mark. The jug is:
questions.explanation_correct: Water up to the middle mark means the jug is half-full.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The middle of a container means it is half-full — filled to 50%.

questions.question_text: Anu fills a bucket using a mug. She uses 8 mugs of water. The bucket holds:
questions.explanation_correct: Since Anu used mugs as her unit, the bucket holds 8 mugs of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The unit used was mugs, so the answer is in mugs. Not litres, cups, or cm.

questions.question_text: It takes 5 cups to fill Bottle A and 3 cups to fill Bottle B. Which bottle has more capacity?
questions.explanation_correct: Bottle A holds 5 cups while Bottle B holds only 3 cups. 5 > 3, so Bottle A has more capacity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: More cups needed means more capacity. 5 cups > 3 cups, so Bottle A holds more.

questions.question_text: Mummy uses a big pot to cook dal and a small bowl for chutney. Which has more capacity?
questions.explanation_correct: The big pot has more capacity than the small bowl because it is much larger.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bigger containers generally hold more. A cooking pot holds much more than a small bowl.

questions.question_text: Which holds more juice: a teaspoon or a glass?
questions.explanation_correct: A glass holds much more juice than a teaspoon. A glass can hold many teaspoonfuls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A teaspoon is tiny and holds very little compared to a glass.

questions.question_text: Ravi pours water into a glass until it is exactly half-full. Then he pours the same amount again. Now the glass is:
questions.explanation_correct: Half-full + half-full = full. The glass is now full.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding the same amount as what makes half-full gives another half, filling the glass completely.

questions.question_text: A tank needs 10 buckets to fill it. Anu has poured 6 buckets so far. How many more buckets does she need?
questions.explanation_correct: 10 - 6 = 4. Anu needs 4 more buckets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Subtract what she has poured from the total: 10 - 6 = 4 more buckets.

questions.question_text: True or False: A bathtub holds more water than a teacup.
questions.explanation_correct: True. A bathtub is very large and holds much more water than a tiny teacup.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bathtubs are among the largest household containers. They hold vastly more than teacups.

questions.question_text: True or False: An empty bottle has more water than a full bottle.
questions.explanation_correct: False. An empty bottle has no water. A full bottle has the most water it can hold.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Empty means no water. Full means maximum water. So a full bottle has more water.

questions.question_text: Container X takes 7 glasses to fill. Container Y takes 7 glasses to fill. What can we say?
questions.explanation_correct: Both containers take the same number of glasses (7) to fill, so they have the same capacity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same number of the same-sized glasses means equal capacity.

questions.question_text: Which container has the most capacity?
questions.explanation_correct: A water tank has the most capacity. It can hold thousands of glasses of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A water tank is the largest container among these. A thimble is the smallest.

questions.question_text: Arrange from holds least to holds most: a pond, a cup, a bucket.
questions.explanation_correct: Least to most: cup (smallest), bucket (medium), pond (largest).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A cup holds the least, then a bucket, and a pond holds the most water.

questions.question_text: Sita has 3 bottles. Bottle A is full, Bottle B is half-full, and Bottle C is empty. All bottles are the same size. Which has the least water?
questions.explanation_correct: Bottle C is empty, so it has the least water (none at all).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Empty means zero water. Half-full has some. Full has the most. Empty has the least.

questions.question_text: A jug takes 4 cups to fill. How many cups are needed to fill 3 such jugs?
questions.explanation_correct: 1 jug = 4 cups. 3 jugs = 3 x 4 = 12 cups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 jugs x 4 cups = 12 cups in total.

questions.question_text: Which holds less: a bowl or a lake?
questions.explanation_correct: A bowl holds much less water than a lake. A lake is a very large body of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lakes are enormous. A bowl is a small kitchen item that holds very little in comparison.

questions.question_text: Rani uses a small cup and fills a bottle with 12 cups. If she uses a bigger cup, will she need more or fewer cups?
questions.explanation_correct: Bigger cups hold more each time, so fewer are needed to fill the same bottle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bigger units cover more capacity each, so fewer are needed.

questions.question_text: A water bottle is full. Arjun drinks half of it. The bottle is now:
questions.explanation_correct: If Arjun drank half, the bottle is now half-full.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Full minus half equals half-full.

questions.question_text: Which of these is used to measure capacity?
questions.explanation_correct: A measuring cup is used to measure how much a container holds (capacity).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A ruler measures length. A balance measures weight. A clock measures time. A measuring cup measures capacity.

questions.question_text: Bottle P holds 6 glasses and Bottle Q holds 9 glasses. How many more glasses does Bottle Q hold?
questions.explanation_correct: 9 - 6 = 3. Bottle Q holds 3 more glasses than Bottle P.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We subtract: 9 - 6 = 3 glasses more.

questions.question_text: Fill in the blank: A glass with no water is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A glass with no water is empty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No water means the glass is empty.

questions.question_text: Grandma has a big pot and a small pan. She wants to make soup for 10 people. Which should she use?
questions.explanation_correct: The big pot has more capacity, so it can hold enough soup for 10 people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A small pan would not hold enough soup for 10 people. The big pot has more capacity.

questions.question_text: A mug holds 2 cups of water. How many cups of water do 5 mugs hold?
questions.explanation_correct: 5 mugs x 2 cups = 10 cups of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 5 mugs, each holding 2 cups: 5 x 2 = 10 cups.

questions.question_text: Which can hold more milk: a baby's bottle or a cow's pail?
questions.explanation_correct: A cow's pail (milking bucket) holds much more milk than a small baby bottle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A milking pail is much larger than a baby bottle and holds more milk.

questions.question_text: Three identical glasses: Glass 1 is full, Glass 2 is half-full, Glass 3 is full. Which two have the same amount of water?
questions.explanation_correct: Glass 1 and Glass 3 are both full, so they have the same amount of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both Glass 1 and Glass 3 are full. Glass 2 is only half-full.

questions.question_text: A tank needs 20 buckets to be full. It currently has 8 buckets of water. Is the tank more than half-full or less?
questions.explanation_correct: Half of 20 is 10. Since the tank has only 8 buckets (less than 10), it is less than half-full.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Half of 20 = 10. The tank has 8 which is less than 10, so it is less than half-full.

questions.question_text: True or False: A spoon holds more water than a bucket.
questions.explanation_correct: False. A bucket holds much, much more water than a spoon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Buckets are large containers. Spoons hold only a tiny amount.

questions.question_text: Anu fills a jug to the top and then pours out all the water. The jug is now:
questions.explanation_correct: After pouring out ALL the water, the jug is empty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pouring out all the water leaves the jug with nothing — it is empty.

questions.question_text: Pot A needs 15 cups of water and Pot B needs 10 cups. How many more cups does Pot A need?
questions.explanation_correct: 15 - 10 = 5. Pot A needs 5 more cups than Pot B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We subtract: 15 - 10 = 5 cups more.

questions.question_text: Which has the least capacity?
questions.explanation_correct: A cup has the least capacity among bathtub, cup, bucket, and drum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A cup is the smallest container in the list.

questions.question_text: Nita wants to water her garden. Should she use a spoon or a watering can?
questions.explanation_correct: A watering can holds much more water and is designed for watering gardens. A spoon would take too long.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A watering can has much more capacity and is practical for watering a garden.

questions.question_text: A bottle is half-full. Tara pours in more water until it is full. How much water did she add?
questions.explanation_correct: The bottle was half-full. To make it full, she needed to add another half. So she added half a bottle's worth of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Full - half-full = half. She added half a bottle's worth of water.

questions.question_text: A pot holds 8 glasses of water. 2 pots will hold ___ glasses of water.
questions.explanation_correct: 2 pots x 8 glasses = 16 glasses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2 pots of 8 glasses each: 8 + 8 = 16 glasses.

questions.question_text: Arrange from holds most to holds least: a glass, a tank, a bottle.
questions.explanation_correct: Most to least: tank (largest), bottle (medium), glass (smallest).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A tank holds the most, then a bottle, then a glass.

questions.question_text: True or False: Half-full means the same as half-empty.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Half-full and half-empty both describe a container filled to the middle. They mean the same amount.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both terms describe the same level of filling — exactly in the middle.

questions.question_text: A big glass holds 3 cups of water. A small glass holds 1 cup. Which holds the most water?
questions.explanation_correct: 1 big glass = 3 cups. 2 small glasses = 2 cups. 3 > 2, so the big glass holds more.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1 big glass (3 cups) vs 2 small glasses (2 cups). The big glass holds more.

questions.question_text: What does capacity tell us about a container?
questions.explanation_correct: Capacity tells us how much a container can hold.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Capacity is about how much a container holds. Weight tells heaviness. Height tells tallness.

questions.question_text: Mama uses 6 cups of water to fill a kettle. Papa uses 4 cups. If they use different cup sizes, who probably used bigger cups?
questions.explanation_correct: Papa used fewer cups (4 < 6) to fill the same kettle, so his cups must be bigger.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fewer cups needed means bigger cups. Papa used only 4 cups, so his are bigger.

questions.question_text: Two bottles look the same size from outside. One is thick-walled and one is thin-walled. Which holds more inside?
questions.explanation_correct: The thin-walled bottle has more space inside because less space is taken up by the walls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thicker walls take up more space, leaving less room inside. The thin-walled bottle holds more.

questions.question_text: Which shows the correct order from empty to full?
questions.explanation_correct: From empty to full: empty (nothing), half-full (middle), full (to the top).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from least to most water is: empty, half-full, full.

questions.question_text: A bucket holds 20 mugs of water. If we pour out 7 mugs, how many mugs of water are left?
questions.explanation_correct: 20 - 7 = 13. There are 13 mugs of water left in the bucket.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We subtract what was poured out: 20 - 7 = 13 mugs left.

questions.question_text: Hari says a tall thin bottle holds more than a short wide bowl. Is he always correct?

options.text: No, the wide bowl might hold more

questions.explanation_correct: Not necessarily. A short wide bowl can hold more than a tall thin bottle. Shape affects capacity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Height alone does not determine capacity. Width matters too. A wide bowl may hold more.

questions.question_text: True or False: A half-full glass has more water than a full glass of the same size.
questions.explanation_correct: False. A full glass has more water than a half-full glass of the same size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Full means maximum water. Half-full is only half of that. Full > half-full.

questions.question_text: A jug holds 5 glasses. To fill 4 jugs you need ___ glasses.
questions.explanation_correct: 4 jugs x 5 glasses = 20 glasses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4 jugs of 5 glasses each: 4 x 5 = 20 glasses.

questions.question_text: Which word describes a container that can hold a lot?
questions.explanation_correct: A container that can hold a lot is said to have large capacity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Light describes weight. Short describes length. Empty means nothing inside. Large capacity means holds a lot.

questions.question_text: Priya fills a tank using buckets. She used 10 small buckets yesterday and 6 big buckets today. Both times the tank was full. What can we say?

options.text: The big buckets hold more than the small buckets

questions.explanation_correct: Fewer big buckets (6) filled the same tank as more small buckets (10). So big buckets hold more water each.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fewer buckets needed for the same tank means each bucket held more. The big buckets hold more.
